body:
From the ZFS source you linked

> The only flag combination which matches the behavior of zfs_space() is FALLOC_FL_KEEP_SIZE | FALLOC_FL_PUNCH_HOLE.

Rclone only uses `FALLOC_FL_KEEP_SIZE`

Reading [the man page](http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/fallocate.2.html) I think it would be safe to add `FALLOC_FL_PUNCH_HOLE` since rclone only ever preallocates space on a 0 sized file.

> The FALLOC_FL_PUNCH_HOLE flag was introduced in the 2.6.38 kernel.

The go runtime supports down to 2.6.23 so this would cut off a few versions.

However I think this (from the man page) is more of a barrier to adding that flag unconditionally.

>        Not all filesystems support FALLOC_FL_PUNCH_HOLE; if a filesystem
>        doesn't support the operation, an error is returned.  The operation
>        is supported on at least the following filesystems:
> 
>        *  XFS (since Linux 2.6.
>        *  ext4 (since Linux 3.0)
>        *  Btrfs (since Linux 3.7)
>        *  tmpfs(5) (since Linux 3.5)"

Pre allocate is a performance optimization only, it doesn't affect correctness.  I added to speed up Windows where it is very effective, the Linux support was an afterthought.

Perhaps the best solution might be for rclone to detect the "operation not supported" error (syscall.ENOTSUP) and turn off pre allocate?

Or I guess it could try `FALLOC_FL_KEEP_SIZE | FALLOC_FL_PUNCH_HOLE` and if that failed turn it off.

I had a go at that here - can you give it a go?  It should print some log messages which I'll remove once it is working.

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.46.0-108-g88b893d1-fix-3066-preallocate-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)
Oh I should have mentioned, I'm running rclone on a *nix box and performing the operations on the box, Windows is not involved in anyway.

> Oh I should have mentioned, I'm running rclone on a *nix box and performing the operations on the box, Windows is not involved in anyway.

Understood! Give the beta above a go and tell me what you think - thanks!
@ellisonpatterson did you have a go with the above beta?
Apologize about the delay! I modified my system configuration so I am no longer seeing the issue but the release above did not display that error message any longer.
Thanks for testing! I've merged this to master now which means it will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org) in 15-30 mins and released in v1.48

Having this option would still be useful. For instance, when preallocating a file on btrfs, data written to the preallocated space doesn't get compressed, which means I have to manually run a second pass to re-compress all the files after rclone finishes.

@DaMatrix 

You can disable preallocate with

#### --local-no-preallocate

Disable preallocation of disk space for transferred files.

Preallocation of disk space helps prevent filesystem fragmentation.
However, some virtual filesystem layers (such as Google Drive File
Stream) may incorrectly set the actual file size equal to the
preallocated space, causing checksum and file size checks to fail.
Use this flag to disable preallocation.

Properties:

- Config:      no_preallocate
- Env Var:     RCLONE_LOCAL_NO_PREALLOCATE
- Type:        bool
- Default:     false

Oh, awesome! I hadn't seen that option because it wasn't available in the rclone version I had installed (latest from the Debian repo). Manually updated to the latest and it works like a charm. Thanks!

issue.title: local: preallocate_unix does not preallocate

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### The associated forum post URL from `https://forum.rclone.org`



#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?
The unix routines to PreAllocate a file don't actually PreAllocate 


#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)
master


#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (e.g. Windows 7, 64 bit)
Linux, OpenSuse Tumbleweed, x86_64, BTRFS


#### Which cloud storage system are you using? (e.g. Google Drive)
local


#### The command you were trying to run (e.g. `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
rclone copy


#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (e.g. output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
```
2025/06/22 17:01:29 DEBUG : sub/file2.a358e130.partial: should preallocate: true
2025/06/22 17:01:29 DEBUG : sub/file2.a358e130.partial: preallocating: 1536
2025/06/22 17:01:29 DEBUG : preAllocate: size is now 0, <nil>
```

#### Source of bug (I added this header)
The usage of FALLOC_FL_KEEP_SIZE is incorrect. This flag tells falloc to maintain the size of the file, which is the opposite of pre*allocating*

A rough fix below seems to work
```diff
diff --git a/lib/file/preallocate_unix.go b/lib/file/preallocate_unix.go
index dc05fc60e..f3a7511d9 100644
--- a/lib/file/preallocate_unix.go
+++ b/lib/file/preallocate_unix.go
@@ -14,8 +14,8 @@ import (
 
 var (
 	fallocFlags = [...]uint32{
-		unix.FALLOC_FL_KEEP_SIZE,                             // Default
-		unix.FALLOC_FL_KEEP_SIZE | unix.FALLOC_FL_PUNCH_HOLE, // for ZFS #3066
+		0,                             // Default
+		unix.FALLOC_FL_PUNCH_HOLE, // for ZFS #3066
 	}
```

However, the second set of flags will not work as FALLOC_FL_PUNCH_HOLE is required to be OR'd with FALLOC_FL_KEEP_SIZE according to [the manual](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/fallocate.2.html). Additionally, I propose that we look into using ftruncate if the user allows us to use sparse files.
